attachments.text: Presentation about Dagger 2 which I gave at Mobilization 2015 - <http://2015.mobilization.pl/> Source code is available: <https://github.com/frogermcs/GithubClient> More about DI/Dagger 2: Migration from Dagger to Dagger 2 - <http://frogermcs.github.io/dagger-1-to-2-migration/> Intro to DI - <http://frogermcs.github.io/dependency-injection-with-dagger-2-introdution-to-di/> Dagger 2 API - <http://frogermcs.github.io/dependency-injection-with-dagger-2-the-api/> Scopes in Dagger 2 - <http://frogermcs.github.io/dependency-injection-with-dagger-2-custom-scopes/> Dagger 2 - graph creation performance - <http://frogermcs.github.io/dagger-graph-creation-performance/>

it is difficult

keep your state away from your views as much as you can

<@U0NHHTE2H|efemer> has joined the channel

<@U0552GXEN>: I was talking with Jason about it the other day. I've done it in the past in a Kotlin app: No Fragments, but also no XML-inflated layouts thanks to Anko, just custom Views.
anko :-1:
<@U060Q7J2Y>: why?
giving up the resource system
not true
> no XML-inflated layouts
you mean the different configurations?
yep
also, i find xml more declarative anyway
<@U060Q7J2Y>: <https://github.com/Kotlin/anko/blob/master/doc/ADVANCED.md#configuration-qualifiers>
gross
not as gross as XML
hardly
and XML resources use the same APIs that are available to everyone else
so if Anko isn't your bag, you can write one that works better
but I enjoy not paying the XML penalty
android layouts are XML, all styles, style inheritance, ~configuration~ etc are based on inflation. Using a DSL breaks all of it.
i dont find XML to be a penalty at all
styles are just maps of properties
Interesting approach <@U053LEHJN>. yeah I was talking with Jason about it too along with Mitchell and we were all onboard with possibly trying a new approach and making an app with no fragments.

text: It’s just something pretty simple, I’m trying to explore as much as possible of rx. But this struck me as weird
As a Transformer returns an Observable, and I just chain .subscribeOn and .observeOn. Which both also return an Observable
Are you sure e.getMessage() is not null?
It returned 404 page not found before
I mean the getMessage
It’s a API call with retrofit

```
Caused by: java.lang.NullPointerException: println needs a message
                                                                                 at android.util.Log.println_native(Native Method)
                                                                                 at android.util.Log.i(Log.java:207)
                                                                                 at be.simon.vergauwen.moviepop.MainActivity$1.onError(MainActivity.java:45)
```
I’ll put a check in place
Try it :simple_smile: I think the Transformer code is correct
and yes compose will affect the whole stream instead the next one (flatmap)
And instead creating a new Observable (again flatmap) compose will transform the current Observable
Okay, that’s what I want here
And you’re correct it was just the Throwable was null. (weird)
But the whole thing stopped working
and when I place .observeOn & .subscribeOn before .compose
it works perfectly
everytime.
That’s fine by me, but that something I’d run into again with different function chaining. So I’m trying to figure out why
Hmmm
I think it’s because you already subscribing when compose take action
I think the correct way to use transformer is to put the observeOn and subscribeOn inside the transform and put the subscribe outside it
because in many case you may use same observeOn and subscribeOn but mostly you’ll put different thing in your subscribe
And I just realize something wrong with your code
